newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Treasuries dive on NAPM, bond ends down 2 pts.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Treasuries dive on NAPM, bond ends down 2 pts.

text.p: Prices of U.S. Treasury securities ended sharply lower on Friday, with the benchmark 30-year bond diving two full points, as further signs of a turbo-charged economy sent up an inflation yellow flag.
"The selloff was violent," said Michelle Colley Laughlin, Treasury strategist at Prudential Securities Inc.
"I had come in today anticipating that we were at risk of a correction."
Indeed, the market may have gotten more than it bargained for, as a crush of economic data offered much trading fodder.

The day kicked off with the July employment report, which showed the country added a whopping 316,000 new jobs in the month, eclipsing analysts' expectations for a 193,000-new-job gain. Meanwhile, the unemployment rate slipped two notches to 4.8 percent from 5.0 percent in June.
Treasury bond prices chopped and changed after the report, immediately erasing a 7/32 gain and converting it into a 7/32 loss, as dealers focused on the payrolls' increase.
But minutes later, the benchmark issue was back up at unchanged as traders shifted their focus from the payrolls jump to an unchanged reading on average hourly earnings.
Earnings were flat at $12.23 an hour. June's figure was revised up one cent from $12.22 originally.
The market momentarily embraced what it called "good news" on wages, and proceeded to hover around slightly lower levels until the selling flood gates opened at 1000 EDT/1400 GMT.

At that time, the National Association of Purchasing Management (NAPM) released its much-watched survey of industry activity. NAPM's diffusion index soared to 58.6 percent in July, its highest since November 1994 when it registered 59.1 percent. The production index printed 64.4, a 9-1/2-year high, and the new orders component hit a three-year peak.
"(The NAPM) index served as a catalyst for some profit-taking before the refunding" next week, said Matthew Alexy, chief markets strategist for fixed income at Credit Suisse First Boston Corp.

Alexy was referring to the Treasury's sale next Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday of $16.0 billion in three-year notes, $12.0 billion in 10-year notes, and $10.0 billion in 30-year bonds, respectively. The quarterly refunding effort will total $38.0 billion compared to $39.0 billion in May.
The prices index shot to 53.6 from 48.1, but Norbert Ore, head of the NAPM survey committee was not overly concerned.
In a teleconference with members of the financial press following the July NAPM's release, Ore said purchasing managers were not yet voicing concerns about rising prices.
Asked if price pressures stood toward the bottom of a list of member concerns, Ore responded: "(Price jitters) were not on the list at all."
But the very fact that the prices component leapt 5.5 percentage points spooked the Treasury market, dealers said.
Combined with gains in new orders and production -- other key components of the index -- bonds collapsed, falling more than two full points.
Still, Alexy pointed out that the selling was overdone. "If prices everywhere in the economy were going up 0.1 percentage point, the prices index in NAPM would be 100."
The benchmark 30-year U.S. Treasury security ended the day down 2-3/32 at 102-7/32 to yield 6.46 percent compared to 6.30 at Thursday's close.

Asked what type of damage Friday's freefall may have done to the technical picture for Treasuries, David Ging, technical analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette Securities Corp, said: "We've at least put in a near-term top."
Ging pointed to 114-19/32 and 113-19/32 as two potential retracement targets for T-bond futures next week, but said upcoming supply would make it tough for the market to rally.
The University of Michigan also released its July final index of consumer sentiment Friday. It soared to an all-time high of 107.1, up from 104.5 in the final June report.
Also, the Commerce Department reported personal income up 0.6 percent in June and spending up 0.3 percent.
